questions.principle: Moral capital is accumulated through consistent action

answers.4: solid — people generally trust my word
answers.3: developing — building credibility in some areas
answers.1: damaged or nonexistent — I have to prove myself constantly

questions.text: Relational credit from past faithfulness that I could draw on is ...

answers.4: substantial — I have real reserves with most people
answers.5: abundant — deep relational capital built over years
answers.3: moderate — some credit in some relationships
answers.1: empty — I've burned through whatever I had

questions.text: My track record of keeping commitments gives me ...

answers.4: good credibility — people expect me to deliver
answers.5: strong credibility — my commitment is trusted implicitly
answers.2: limited credibility — I have to over-prove myself
answers.1: no credibility — people doubt my follow-through

questions.text: People coming to me for ethical guidance or character references is ...

answers.4: common — people see me as a resource
answers.5: frequent — I'm a go-to person for moral questions

questions.text: My integrity compounding into doors opening is ...

answers.4: real — my character opens doors regularly
answers.5: substantial — my reputation is a genuine asset
answers.1: not happening — if anything, doors are closing

remediation.advice: Moral capital is built one kept promise at a time. If you lack credibility, the answer isn't marketing — it's accumulating a track record. Every commitment kept is a deposit. Every promise broken is a withdrawal. Build the account.

scripture.text: The integrity of the upright guides them, but the crookedness of the treacherous destroys them.
